title: Christian Gonzalez on Patriots extension talks: ‘I don’t want to be anywhere else’
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Christian Gonzalez aims to sign a contract extension with the New England Patriots this offseason.
Gonzalez is on the final year of his rookie contract, and the Patriots have a fifth-year option available.
Teammate Carlton Davis supports Gonzalez, calling him deserving of being one of the highest-paid corners.

title: Man dies after being struck by MBTA commuter rail train in Haverhill
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: An adult man died after being struck by an MBTA commuter rail train in Haverhill early Tuesday morning.
The man intentionally entered the track near the Cross Street crossing, according to Transit Police.
The incident caused cancellations and significant delays on the Haverhill Line, impacting morning commuters.

title: Boston Raising Cane’s faces eviction over chicken finger odor, lawsuit says
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Raising Cane's in Boston filed a lawsuit against landlord 755 Boylston, LLC over alleged extortion related to chicken finger odor complaints.
The landlord is accused of trying to bring in a Panda Express next door, violating Raising Cane's exclusive chicken restaurant rights.
Raising Cane's spent over $200,000 on odor mitigation, claiming building issues cause the smell, not the restaurant operations.

title: Revolution reveal ‘Independence Day’ jersey
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: New England Revolution unveiled a special 'Independence Day' jersey with a fireworks-themed design for the 250th national birthday.
The jersey, paired with navy shorts and red, white, and blue socks, will be worn for the 2026 and 2027 MLS seasons.
Fans can purchase the jersey at pop-up locations on Feb. 10 at Boston's Old State House and Ducali Pizzeria & Bar.

title: About a dozen vehicles damaged by a bridge joint on I-91 in Western Mass.
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: About a dozen vehicles were damaged by a protruding bridge joint on I-91 near mile marker 9 in Western Mass.
MassDOT maintenance crews cut down the raised joint, and State Police assisted disabled vehicles at the scene.
MassDOT plans to work with a contractor for a long-term repair; drivers can file claims for personal injury damages.

title: North Andover officer shot by colleague argues judge is biased and should be removed
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Kelsey Fitzsimmons argues Judge McCarthy-Neyman is biased, seeking recusal in her case at Essex Superior Court.
Fitzsimmons was shot by a colleague during a restraining order service; judge questioned compliance and probation details.
Fitzsimmons's lawyers allege judge's potential bias due to town's financial interest; recusal hearing set for March 9.

title: Eli Lilly snaps up Watertown biotech in $2.4 billion deal
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Eli Lilly acquired Watertown-based Orna Therapeutics for $2.4 billion, marking a significant biotech transaction.
Orna Therapeutics is developing treatments using circular RNA and lipids to help produce cell therapies in patients.
The acquisition follows Eli Lilly's purchase of Scorpion and Verve Therapeutics, expanding its presence in Massachusetts.

title: Boston man paroled after serving 16 years of life sentence for fatal stabbing outside bar
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Corey Patterson, convicted of second-degree murder in 2009, was paroled after 16 years in prison.
Patterson was sentenced to life in prison for fatally stabbing Gregory Phillips outside an Allston bar.
His parole conditions include electronic monitoring, curfew, no contact with the victim's family, and mental health counseling.

title: ‘You’re going to feel the pain’: Kurt Warner’s advice to Drake Maye after losing Super Bowl LX
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Patriots' Drake Maye received advice from Kurt Warner after losing Super Bowl LX to the Seahawks, 29-13.
Warner emphasized processing the loss's pain as part of Maye's development after the Patriots' turnaround season.
The Patriots, led by coach Mike Vrabel, aim to build on their unexpected Super Bowl appearance in 2026.

title: Making movies, like making sausages, is not pretty. Just ask John Sayles.
author: Lauren Daley
bullets: John Sayles discusses his new novel 'Crucible,' set in Detroit during Henry Ford's era, highlighting class conflicts and industrial themes.
Sayles, known for films like 'Matewan' and 'Lone Star,' explores historical arcs in his novels and tackles adapting scripts amid funding challenges.
Sayles shares insights on storytelling formats, choosing between screenplays and novels, and his experiences in both the film and publishing industries.
